item.title: CITIESair Blog - A Guide to Take Care of Your Respiratory Health
item.dc:creator: citiesair
item.content:encoded:
Personally, I have suffered from respiratory issues since coming to Abu Dhabi. As a result, I did research into air pollution and developed the habit of tracking air quality daily to minimize my exposure. Inadvertently, this process of becoming a citizen scientist has made me more aware of the dire situation of air pollution juxtaposed with low awareness and action-taking within the community and the region as a whole.

The isolated location of schools and universities campuses, like NYU Abu Dhabi, gives us a sense of comfort and cleanliness: we are not constantly surrounded by vehicles or factories. The issue of air pollution thus gets selectively compartmentalized. It is hard to pay attention to the air we breathe in, it is not a priority. Little do we know, air pollution from traffic, industries, oil refineries, and sandstorms in other parts of the country and in neighboring countries can disperse all over the region, regardless of proximity to emission source.

A word from the author

As air quality and air pollution can be complicated topics, this guide is divided into bite-site articles that can help you become familiar with some of the terminologies and ways to protect your respiratory well-beings. It is definitely not an exhaustive nor a must-do list. You can always refer to Further Reading for more detailed breakdowns and visualizations.

1. What is particulate matter air pollution?

2. Particulate matter in Abu Dhabi

3. Ways to protect yourself

Further Reading

  • Detailed data visualization and analysis of air pollution for all countries: Outdoor Air Pollution, Our World in Data
  • Stories of air pollution from all over the world:
    The Weight of Numbers: Air Pollution and PM2.5, Undark
  • By combining photographs qualitative evidence, with quantitative graphs, Reuters succeeded in bridging the gap between the physicality of air pollution and scientific data:
    A window into Delhis deadly pollution, Reuter Graphics
  • How the COVID-19 pandemic inadvertently improve air quality across the world:
    A breath of fresh air, Reuter Graphics
  • ... with more to be updated

item.title: twentytwenty

item.title: Particulate Matter in Abu Dhabi
item.dc:creator: citiesair
item.content:encoded:
TL;DR: Particulate matter level in Abu Dhabi has been decreasing over the past few years; however, it still remains higher than the WHO's annual limit. Thus, monitoring air quality and taking actions to protect our respiratory well-beings is of significant importance.

1. The Good

There are currently over 20 air quality monitoring stations across the Emirate of Abu Dhabi, reporting data on:

  • Particulate matter (PM)
  • Ozone (O3)
  • Nitrogen dioxide (NO2)
  • Sulfur dioxide (SO2)

This network of monitoring stations (adairquality.ae) is a great initiative to keep track of air quality as a part of the regulatory process towards a more sustainable-living future in the UAE.

Annually, the Environment Agency Abu Dhabi (EAD) publish a summary report from this network of monitoring stations. It is evident that there is a downward trend since 2012 for PM10 (coarse particulate matter). On the other hand, PM2.5 (fine particulate matter) witnessed a slight upward trend, albeit with a recent sharp drop from 2018 to 2019.

Independently, the US Embassy at Abu Dhabi and US Consulate at Dubai also measures PM2.5 level and provides public access to the data via AirNow program. It is evident that there has been a recent downward trend in PM2.5 level between 2019 and 2020 from this data source:

This comes at no surprise considering the COVID-19 pandemic has led to a significant reduction in emission activities. Whether this downward trend in emission across the world continues or not is up for debate[1].

On top of that, particulate matter concentration in the UAE exhibits a strong seasonal fluctuation, with highest peaks in the summer and lower levels in winter months. This phenomenon likely linked to frequent dust storm in the summer coupled with increased energy demand[2]. As most people stay indoors during the summer, they inadvertently lower their exposure to the highest PM concentrations.


2. The Bad

That said, annual PM2.5 concentration is still 2 to 4 times higher than the limit set by WHO (10g/m3) over the past 3 years. In fact, all the UAE population are subjected to annual average PM2.5 levels higher than the guidelines of WHO[2].

Research has shown that while environmental disease burden in the UAE is lower than global average, outdoor air quality remains the number one leading factor for premature death[3]. In fact, a 2013 study found that 7.3% of all deaths in the UAE could be attributed to outdoor air pollution.[4]

Air quality in Abu Dhabi and the region as a whole is a complex and dynamic issue due to its unique geographic and socioeconomic characteristics. Located in an arid region with little vegetation, Abu Dhabi is often prone to natural dust storms and dust events that result in high concentration of particulate matter, during which people, especially those with pre-existing respiratory conditions, are strongly advised to stay indoors[5][6].

While natural pollutants such as dust storms make up most of the coarser particulate matter (PM10), anthropogenic emissions (traffic, refineries, water desalination plants, construction activities...) contribute to fine and ultrafine particulate matter (PM2.5)[7]. Remember: the smaller the particulate matter, the more dangerous it it.

The photo below shows particulate matter collected on Teflon filters during different occasions in the UAE. On days with dust storms, the color is noticeably yellow. However, on "clearer" days whiteout dust stroms, the color is much darker, which can be attributed to black (elemental) carbon and anthropogenic emissions:

Without getting into the scientific details of air pollution, it is worth noting that anthropogenic air pollutants such as SO2 and NO2 can also interact with natural pollutants to create secondary pollutants, exacerbating air quality[5].

3. The Future

The UAE is supporting ongoing efforts to curb emission and adapt sustainable-living strategies to reduce the mortality rate from household and ambient air pollution from 64.8 (2017) to 60.2 per 100,000 by 2030[8]. One thing we can all hope for is that the decreasing trend in air pollution in the UAE continues well into the near future.

At the same time, it will take years for the top-down approach to systematically reduce pollutant levels below the recommended guideline by the WHO. In the immediate future, we can all do our parts by adopting a more conscious approach to quantifying air quality and reduce our personal exposure to air pollution, which will be explored in the final article of this series: 3. Ways to protect yourself.

Citation

  1. Gardiner, Beth. "Why COVID-19 Will End Up Harming The Environment". Science, 2021, https://www.nationalgeographic.com/science/article/why-covid-19-will-end-up-harming-the-environment. Accessed 11 Apr 2021.
  2. Al-Taani, A.A., Nazzal, Y., Howari, F.M. et al. Long-term trends in ambient fine particulate matter from 1980 to 2016 in United Arab Emirates. Environ Monit Assess 191, 143 (2019). https://doi.org/10.1007/s10661-019-7259-9
  3. Gibson, Jacqueline MacDonald, and Zeinab S. Farah. "Environmental risks to public health in the United Arab Emirates: a quantitative assessment and strategic plan." Environmental health perspectives 120.5 (2012): 681-686.
  4. Gibson, Jacqueline MacDonald, et al. "Deaths and medical visits attributable to environmental pollution in the United Arab Emirates." PloS one 8.3 (2013): e57536.
  5. Hamdan, Nasser M., Hussain Alawadhi, and Najeh Jisrawi. "Particulate matter pollution in the United Arab Emirates: elemental analysis and phase identification of fine particulate pollutants." Proceedings of the 2nd world congress on new technologies. 2016.
  6. Bardsley, Daniel. Dust storms prompt concerns over UAE's air quality. The National, 2018. Accessed April 7, 2021. https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/environment/dust-storms-prompt-concerns-over-uae-s-air-quality-1.755594
  7. Hamdan, Nasser M., Hussain Alawadhi, and Najeh Jisrawi. "Elemental and Chemical Analysis of PM10 and PM2. 5 Indoor and Outdoor Pollutants in the UAE." International Journal of Environmental Science and Development 6.8 (2015): 566.
  8. UAE National Air Quality Strategy (2021-2031), Stakeholders Workshop: Global Green Growth Institute (GGGI); 2020. Accessed April 7, 2021. https://gggi.org/uae-national-air-quality-strategy-2021-2031-stakeholders-workshop/

item.title: What is Particulate Matter
item.dc:creator: citiesair
item.content:encoded:
TL;DR: Particulate matter is microscopic, thus capable of penetrating deep into our lungs and bloodstream, causing damage to our bodies. While there are other kinds of air pollution, such as ground-level ozone, nitrogen dioxide... this article focuses on particulate matter as it poses the most significant threat to our health.

1. Microscopic Size

Particulate matter (PM) consists of microscopic particles small enough to be suspended in the air for a long period of time. Depends on the size of the particles, particulate matter can be further broken down to: PM10 (coarse particles less than 10 micrometers across) and PM2.5 (very fine particles less than 2.5 micrometers across). PM2.5 particles are often the direct result of human-made activities, such as coal and diesel burning, vehicle emission, construction site, and agriculture waste combustion.

2. Microscopic Comparison

Tiny as they are, PM2.5 particles are invisible to our naked eyes. The background of this page is an image of a single human hair magnified 1,000 - 10,000 times depending on your screen size. Scroll down to see how particulate matter compares.

Human hair
50 m (0.05 mm)

Coarse particle PM10
10 m

Red blood cell
7 m

Fine particle PM2.5
<2.5 m

Coronavirus
0.1 m

3. Microscopic Killer

As we can see, particulate matter, especially PM2.5 particles, is on the same size magnitude of our cells. Because of this, they can bypass our first line of defense mechanism, such as nasal hairs and mucus. PM2.5 are capable of penetrating deep into our alveoli (tiny air sacks that line the lungs), from which they find their ways into our bloodstream and into other organs, such as the brain, liver, and kidney. As some of their chemical compositions include heavy metals and toxins from anthropogenic activities, they are capable of causing inflammation, oxidative stress, blockage, and ultimately cancer. Acute symptoms such as coughing, sore throat, and breathing difficulty can also occur when exposed to high levels of particulate matter.

Next Articles

2. Particulate matter in Abu Dhabi

3. Ways to protect yourself

item.title: Ways to Protect Yourself
item.dc:creator: citiesair
item.content:encoded:
Any level of air pollution, no matter how low, is harmful to human health

Piazza, Geri. "Air pollution linked to risk of premature death", National Institute of Health, 2018. https://www.nih.gov/news-events/nih-research-matters/air-pollution-linked-risk-premature-death

1. Tracking Air Quality

As discussed in the previous article, it is in our best interest to explore different ways we can protect yourself against air pollution. Tracking air quality is one of them: knowing is knowledge. Often time, air pollution is an invisible problem (except for dust storm events). Fortunately, there is a plethora of websites that provide real-time air quality data. Most of them use a combination of data from official monitoring stations (which can be few and far between) and satellite imagery with sophisticated algorithms to estimate air pollution levels:

  • AQICN
  • IQAir
  • Plumelab

However, due to data-aggregating nature of these websites, real-time data and the way these data is visualized varies quite a lot. A value of 100 might mean Moderate for one site or Unhealthy for others.

That is precisely the reason why this project is born: to provide our NYUAD community a localized and granular network of air quality monitors across campus. It implements the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) air quality index standard, which is the most widely-used system in the world. With its real-time and localized data, it can aid in understanding air pollution and making conscious health decisions.

2. Comparing Different Protective Measures

There are many easy ways we can take to reduce our exposure to harmful levels of particulate air pollution:

Being indoor

In general, indoor air quality can be good if the building comes with a modern integrated HVAC system equipped with air filters. However, indoor microscopic dust concentration can vary considerably from household to household. Air quality can become worse if windows are not appropriately closed when the air is dirty outside. At the same time, emission activities without proper ventilation, such as smoking, cooking, and dusting... can significantly degrade indoor air quality.[3]

Cooking is often a source of emission that we don't pay attention to but can have a negative impact on the air quality, especially grilled and fried food that emits carcinogenic volatile compounds.

HEPA filter

HEPA filter, which stands for high-efficiency particulate air filter, can successfully filter out 99.95% of airborne particles smaller than 2.5m. Made from tightly-packed non-woven fibers, HEPA filters are used in air purifiers and modern HVAC system. It has been estimated that such systems can reduce premature mortality caused by air pollution by up to 2.5%[7].

Cloth mask and surgical mask

Cloth masks, bandanas, and cloth handkerchiefs are often used thanks to their inexpensive price and reusability. They provide a certain degree of protection especially against larger particles; however, they only offer marginal shield against PM2.5 particles. The tighter the fabric is, the better the protection.[4][5][6]

Disposable surgical masks are affordable, convenient, and moderately effective against fine dust particles. If tightly worn, surgical masks can filter between 30%-80% particles while also protecting against water droplets that can carry bacteria and viruses[4][5][6]. However, due to its being mass-produced, tight fit is difficult to achieve for everyone.

N95 mask

N95 masks, if worn properly, can filter at least 95% particulate matter. They are commonly utilized by construction workers and healthcare workers for their great efficiency. During the past few years, N95 masks have gained considerable popularity among people in China and India as they face some of the worst air pollution episodes.[4][5][6]

Citation

  1. Wei Y, Wang Y, Di Q, Choirat C, Wang Y, Koutrakis P, Zanobetti A, Dominici F, Schwartz JD. Short term exposure to fine particulate matter and hospital admission risks and costs in the Medicare population: time stratified, case crossover study. BMJ. 2019 Nov 27;367:l6258. PMID: 31776122; PMCID: PMC6880251.https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.l6258
  2. Schlanger, Zo Legal Levels of Air Pollution Are Killing the Elderly. Quartz, Quartz, 27 Dec. 2017. https://qz.com/1166010/air-pollution-even-at-levels-that-meet-national-standards-causes-premature-death/
  3. Chun Chen, Bin Zhao, Review of relationship between indoor and outdoor particles: I/O ratio, infiltration factor and penetration factor, Atmospheric Environment, Volume 45, Issue 2, 2011, Pages 275-288, ISSN 1352-2310. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.atmosenv.2010.09.048
  4. Shakya, K., Noyes, A., Kallin, R. et al. Evaluating the efficacy of cloth facemasks in reducing particulate matter exposure. J Expo Sci Environ Epidemiol 27, 352357 (2017). https://doi.org/10.1038/jes.2016.42
  5. Bowen, Larry E. Does That Face Mask Really Protect You? Applied Biosafety, vol. 15, no. 2, June 2010, pp. 6771. doi:10.1177/153567601001500204
  6. Langrish, Jeremy P et al. Beneficial cardiovascular effects of reducing exposure to particulate air pollution with a simple facemask. Particle and fibre toxicology vol. 6 8. 13 Mar. 2009. https://dx.doi.org/10.1186%2F1743-8977-6-8
  7. Zhao, D.; Azimi, P.; Stephens, B. Evaluating the Long-Term Health and Economic Impacts of Central Residential Air Filtration for Reducing Premature Mortality Associated with Indoor Fine Particulate Matter (PM2.5) of Outdoor Origin. Int. J. Environ. Res. Public Health 2015, 12, 8448-8479.https://doi.org/10.3390/ijerph120708448
